results.title: The Last Tram
results.brief_description:
This film captured by John ‘Jack’ Anderson, documents the last tram ride through the city of Ballarat in 1971.

The footage was filmed in 1971, with titles and music added for an event held at the Regent Theatre in Ballarat on 5th March 2020, “Large as Life: celebrating the life John ‘Jack’ Anderson”.

results.title: The Last to go
results.creator_credit: John Erman, Interscope Productions and Freyda Rothstein
results.brief_description: This sensitive portrayal of a family relationship traces the path of a seemingly “perfect couple” whose dreams for living happily ever after are painfully shattered. The film begins with Daniel and Mary Ellen moving into their new home. Everything appears to be normal, as Daniel works at furthering his practice as a brain surgeon and his wife devotes herself to their three children. As the film progresses the cracks begin to show, the children grow up and move away, and husband and wife become strangers. As the alienation increases they drift to other people and Daniel begins an affair with one of his nurses while Mary Ellen fantasises about the family gardener. With their marriage well and truly over, Mary Ellen clings to the security of her once happy home, chaining herself to painful memories. Finally, she realises that to move on with her life she must leave the house that once contained the happiness of her marriage. Cast includes Tyne Daly, Terry O’Quinn and Annabeth Gish.

results.title: The Last time I saw Paris
results.creator_credit: Richard Brooks, Jack Cummings and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
results.brief_description: Charles Wills (Van Johnson) is a GI with literary ambitions who goes to Paris and meets and falls in love with the wealthy Helen Ellswirth (Elizabeth Taylor). Charles’ ambition to write a novel falls to pieces as failure to sell his writing causes him to turn to alcohol. During a drunken argument Johnson accidentally locks Helen out of their Parisian apartment, causing her to catch a fatal dose of pneumonia. When Helen dies, custody of their child is granted to Helen’s sister, who always disapproved of her sister’s abusive partner. Shocked into action, Charles returns home and finally finds success as a writer, and the conviction to try and regain custody of his daughter. Based on the tragic love story by F. Scott Fitzgerald. Cast also includes Donna Reed, Walter Pidgeon and Eva Gabor. The tape also includes interviews with Liz Taylor and Richard Burton on literary roles as well as Donna Read on location and in rehearsal.

results.title: The Last temptation of Christ [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Martin Scorsese, Barbara de Fina, Cineplex Odeon and Universal Pictures
results.brief_description: A controversial and challenging film of Jesus Christ’s life. Based on the novel by Nikos Kazantzakis, this Christ is an anguished, vain, sensual man battling the forces of both good and evil. The film traces the conflicts that lead to his final disavowal of the flesh in favour of the life of the son of God. Scorsese had for years tried to film the Kazantzakis’ novel and on its release it was met with great debate and fury. The film, however, is deeply spiritual. With Willem Dafoe as Jesus, Barbara Hershey as Mary Magdalene, Harvey Keitel as Judas, and an impressive cameo by David Bowie as Pontius Pilate. Music by Peter Gabriel.

results.title: The Last Tasmanian: a story of genocide (A)
results.brief_description: This collection of newspaper articles and support material compliments the documentary of the same name.

results.title: The Last Tasmanian : A story of genocide (A)
results.brief_description: This is the story of the swiftest and most comprehensive genocide on record. The Tasmanian Aborignals were an isolated people until British colonisation began. Deliberate government policy and actions meant that a whole society and culture was virtually wiped out within the lifetime of Truganini, known as “The Last Tasmanian”. This documentary takes a conservative position on Tasmanian Aboriginality, which has since been challenged by descendants of indigenous ancestors.

results.title: The Last tall forest
results.brief_description: Presents Tasmania’s remote mountain highland wilderness, the world of high peaks and glacier lakes. In the valleys of Tasmania’s tall forests are the tallest eucalypts of the planet. Scientists have found that plants have existed for 35 million years, but many, such as these tall trees are now threatened by man. Australian animals, such as platypus, wombats, and possums are also shown.
